comment_text.mn139:2.1: Rig Vedic raṇa usually means “joy, delight” (eg. 8.96.16, 10.104.7) or occasionally “war, strife” (6.15.5, 10.112.10, 10.113.4). | See note on MN 137:2.1.
comment_text.mn139:3.1: This is adapted from the first sermon; text has kāmasukhamanuyuñjeyya which is a briefer expression that the original kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogo at SN 56.11:2.3.
comment_text.mn139:3.9: “Popular definitions” is janapadanirutti. | Samaññā (“label”, Sanskrit samājñā) ought not be confused with sāmañña (“agreement”, “equality”, Sanskrit sāmānya).
comment_text.mn139:12.3: None of the terms below are regional or dialectical, so janapadanirutti means “expressions current among the people”, “popular terms”, “common vernacular” rather than “regional dialects”. | A Sanskrit fragment paralleling this passage lists various words for “person”, which likewise are not regional or dialectical terms (SHT ii 163aA3: (jīvo) vā jantur-vā (poṣo) vā pudgalo vā manujo).
comment_text.mn139:12.4: All these terms are either attested in Pali and/or Sanskrit or are readily explicable from Pali roots. This is not about “translating” the Dhamma wholesale, but about using different popular terms, as in the U.S. they refer to the same thing as “soda” or “pop”. | Pātī (“cup”) is from the root √pā, “to drink”, used in Pali for cups of bronze, gold, or silver. | Patta (“bowl”), the masculine form of the same root, is the standard word for a mendicant’s alms bowl. | For vittha (“jar”; variants vitta, piṭṭha) see vitthaka, a small jar for sewing gear (Kd 15:11.5.15). | Sarāva (“scoop”) is a common word for a scoop for water (eg. AN 3.57:3.2, Kd 15:14.3.30, Kv 1.1:356.6; Sanskrit śarāva, eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.1.4.12; Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.8.1; Manu 6.56; also in Jain texts). | For dhāropa (“vessel”) accept variant harosa by analogy with puṭosa (MN 118:8.9), yielding the sense “carrier for food”, “vessel”. | Poṇa (“dish”) is probably a concave dish with “sloped” sides (cp. English “hollowware”). | Pisīlava (“plate”) was used for the butter placed on the altar (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.5.3.6: piśīle vā pātryau vā).
comment_text.mn139:12.12: This passage should be read with Kd 15:33.1.5. There, the Pali depicts the Buddha allowing individual glosses to terms (sakāya niruttiya).
comment_text.mn139:14.3: This was apparently prompted by Subhūti’s support of his fellow monk Saddha at AN 11.14 , for which he was declared the foremost in living without strife (AN 1.201:1.1; he was additionally praised as worthy of donations (AN 1.202:1.1. Subhūti’s meditation is praised at Ud 6.7, and his verse opens the Theragāthā at Thag 1.1.

root_text.mn139:14.3: Subhūti ca pana, bhikkhave, kulaputto araṇapaṭipadaṁ paṭipanno”ti.
root_text.mn139:14.5: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn139:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn139:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn139:2.1: “Mendicants, I shall teach you the analysis of no strife.
translation_text.mn139:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn139:3.1: “Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
translation_text.mn139:3.2: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.mn139:3.3: Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.
translation_text.mn139:3.4: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.
translation_text.mn139:3.5: Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.
translation_text.mn139:3.7: Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.
translation_text.mn139:3.9: Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.
translation_text.mn139:3.10: This is the summary recital for the analysis of no strife.
translation_text.mn139:4.1: ‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’
translation_text.mn139:4.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:4.3: Indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:4.4: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:4.5: Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:4.6: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:4.7: ‘Don’t indulge in sensual pleasure, which is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And don’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.’
translation_text.mn139:4.8: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:5.1: ‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn139:5.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:5.3: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn139:5.4: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn139:5.5: ‘Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One understood the middle way of practice, which gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn139:5.6: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:6.1: ‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.
translation_text.mn139:6.2: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’
translation_text.mn139:6.3: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:7.1: And how is there flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma?
translation_text.mn139:7.2: ‘All those who indulge in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality—low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.3: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.4: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.5: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.6: ‘All those who indulge in self-mortification—painful, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.7: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.8: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in self-mortification are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.9: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.10: ‘All those who have not given up the fetter of continued existence are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.11: In speaking like this, one rebukes some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.12: ‘All those who have given up the fetter of continued existence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:7.13: In speaking like this, one flatters some here.
translation_text.mn139:7.14: That’s how there is flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma.
translation_text.mn139:8.1: And how is there neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma?
translation_text.mn139:8.2: You don’t say: ‘All those who indulge in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality—low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.3: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.4: ‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.7: You don’t say: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.8: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.9: ‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.12: You don’t say: ‘All those who indulge in self-mortification—painful, ignoble, and pointless—are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.13: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.14: ‘The indulgence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.17: You don’t say: ‘All those who have broken off indulging in self-mortification are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.18: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.19: ‘Breaking off the indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.22: You don’t say: ‘All those who have not given up the fetter of continued existence are beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the wrong way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.23: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.24: ‘When the fetter of continued existence is not given up, continued existence is also not given up.’
translation_text.mn139:8.26: You don’t say: ‘All those who have given up the fetter of continued existence are free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and they are practicing the right way.’
translation_text.mn139:8.27: Rather, by saying this you just teach Dhamma:
translation_text.mn139:8.28: ‘When the fetter of continued existence is given up, continued existence is also given up.’
translation_text.mn139:8.30: That’s how there is neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma.
translation_text.mn139:8.31: ‘Know what it means to flatter and to rebuke.
translation_text.mn139:8.32: Knowing these, avoid them, and just teach Dhamma.’
translation_text.mn139:8.33: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:9.1: ‘Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.
translation_text.mn139:9.3: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:9.4: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn139:9.6: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn139:9.10: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn139:9.11: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn139:9.12: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure.
translation_text.mn139:9.13: Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.
translation_text.mn139:9.14: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn139:9.15: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn139:9.18: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening.
translation_text.mn139:9.19: Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.
translation_text.mn139:9.20: ‘Know how to evaluate different kinds of pleasure.
translation_text.mn139:9.22: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:10.1: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’
translation_text.mn139:10.3: but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:10.4: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is untrue, false, and pointless, then to the best of your ability you should not speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.5: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true and correct, but pointless, then you should train yourself not to speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.6: When you know that what you say behind someone’s back is true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.7: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are untrue, false, and pointless, then to the best of your ability you should not speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.8: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true and correct, but pointless, then you should train yourself not to speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.9: When you know that your sharp words in someone’s presence are true, correct, and beneficial, then you should know the right time to speak.
translation_text.mn139:10.10: ‘Don’t talk behind people’s backs, and don’t speak sharply in their presence.’
translation_text.mn139:10.11: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:11.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:11.3: When speaking hurriedly, your body gets tired, your mind gets stressed, your voice gets stressed, your throat gets sore, and your words become unclear and hard to understand.
translation_text.mn139:11.4: When not speaking hurriedly, your body doesn’t get tired, your mind doesn’t get stressed, your voice doesn’t get stressed, your throat doesn’t get sore, and your words are clear and easy to understand.
translation_text.mn139:11.6: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:12.1: ‘Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.’
translation_text.mn139:12.2: That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
translation_text.mn139:12.3: And how do you insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels?
translation_text.mn139:12.4: It’s when among different populations they label the same thing as a ‘cup’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘jar’, a ‘scoop’, a ‘vessel’, a ‘dish’, or a ‘plate’.
translation_text.mn139:12.5: And however it is known among those various populations, you speak accordingly, obstinately sticking to that and insisting:
translation_text.mn139:12.6: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn139:12.7: That’s how you insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels.
translation_text.mn139:12.8: And how do you not insist on popular definitions and overstep normal labels?
translation_text.mn139:12.9: It’s when among different populations they label the same thing as a ‘cup’, a ‘bowl’, a ‘jar’, a ‘scoop’, a ‘vessel’, a ‘dish’, or a ‘plate’.
translation_text.mn139:12.10: And however it is known among those various populations, you speak accordingly, thinking: ‘It seems that the venerables are referring to this.’
translation_text.mn139:12.11: That’s how you don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.
translation_text.mn139:12.12: ‘Don’t insist on popular definitions and don’t overstep normal labels.’
translation_text.mn139:12.13: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
translation_text.mn139:13.1: Now, mendicants, indulging in the happiness of the pleasure linked to sensuality is low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.3: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.4: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.6: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.7: Indulging in self-mortification is painful, ignoble, and pointless. It is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.9: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.10: Breaking off such indulgence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.12: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.13: The middle way of practice that was understood by the Realized One gives vision and knowledge, and leads to peace, direct knowledge, awakening, and extinguishment. It is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.15: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.16: Flattering and rebuking without teaching Dhamma is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.18: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.19: Neither flattering nor rebuking, and just teaching Dhamma is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.21: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.22: Sensual pleasure—a filthy, common, ignoble pleasure—is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.24: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.25: The pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.27: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.28: Saying untrue, false, and pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.30: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.31: Saying true and correct, but pointless things behind someone’s back is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.33: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.34: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things behind someone’s back is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.36: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.37: Saying untrue, false, and pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.39: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.40: Saying true and correct, but pointless things in someone’s presence is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.42: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.43: Saying true, correct, and beneficial things in someone’s presence is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.45: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.46: Speaking hurriedly is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.48: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.49: Speaking unhurriedly is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.51: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.52: Insisting on popular definitions and overriding common usage is a principle beset by pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the wrong way.
translation_text.mn139:13.54: That’s why this is a principle beset by strife.
translation_text.mn139:13.55: Not insisting on popular definitions and not overriding common usage is a principle free of pain, harm, stress, and fever, and it is the right way.
translation_text.mn139:13.57: That’s why this is a principle free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:14.1: So you should train like this: ‘We shall know the principles beset by strife and the principles free of strife.
translation_text.mn139:14.2: Knowing this, we will practice the way free of strife.’
translation_text.mn139:14.3: And, mendicants, the gentleman Subhūti practices the way free of strife.”
translation_text.mn139:14.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn139:14.5: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
